questions.text: The ability to obtain an impression of depth by the superimposition of 2 pictures of the same object is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stereopsis

 

Option A:

 

Stereopsis- ability to obtain an impression of depth by superimposition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Fusion – ability of 2 eyes to produce composite pictures from 2 similar pictures.

 

 

Option C. Amblyopia- partial loss of sight in one or both eyes in the absence of ophthalmoscopic or objective signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stereopsis refers to the ability to perceive depth by integrating the slightly different images from each eye, crucial for tasks that require depth perception.

 

Ref: pg 408/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: In Worth four dot test, the patient’s perception is shown in the image below.  What would be the interpretation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orthophoria

 

Option C.

 

  • The test being done is Worth four-dot test – type of dissociation test.

  • Uses red-green goggles (red before right eye and green before left eye)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Right Suppression: A person with suppression of the right eye will see only two green dots because the right eye (covered by the red lens) suppresses the red dot, and the white dot appears green through the green lens of the left eye.

 

Option B. Left Suppression: A person with suppression of the left eye will see three dots - two green and one red. The left eye (covered by the green lens) suppresses the green dots, and the white dot appears red through the red lens of the right eye.

 

Option D. Diplopia: If the person has double vision (diplopia), they will see five dots - three green (two from the right eye and one white dot seen as green by the left eye) and two red (one from the left eye and one white dot seen as red by the right eye).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Worth Four Dot Test results vary based on the patient's visual condition: right suppression shows two green dots, left suppression shows two green and one red dot, orthophoria shows two green, one red, and one combined dot, and diplopia shows three green and two red dots.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION PAGE 348

questions.text: The only extraocular muscle with sympathetic nerve supply is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Muller’s muscle

 

Option D:

 

MULLER’S  Muscle:

 

  • It is a non-striated muscle of the eyelid.

  • ORIGIN: from inferior striated fibres of levator palpebrae superioris.

  • INSERTION: Orbital margin of tarsal plate.

  • NERVE SUPPLY: sympathetic nerve supply.

  • FUNCTION: Maintains elevation of eyelid.                               

  • Involvement of the Sympathetic chain of head and neck leads to HORNER’S SYNDROME characterised by a triad of ptosis, miosis and anhidrosis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Superior Rectus: This muscle, responsible for elevating the eye, is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III), not by sympathetic nerves.

 

Option B. Levator Palpebrae Superioris (LPS): The LPS raises the upper eyelid and is also innervated by the oculomotor nerve. It is not supplied by sympathetic nerves.

 

Optiion C. Medial Rectus: This muscle, which moves the eye medially (towards the nose), is innervated by the oculomotor nerve as well. It does not receive sympathetic innervation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The only extraocular muscle with sympathetic nerve supply is Müller’s Muscle, a smooth muscle in the upper eyelid that aids in eyelid elevation.

 

Ref: pg 497/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with left oculomotor nerve palsy. Which of the following muscles is spared?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superior oblique

 

Option A:

 

Superior oblique

 

  • ORIGIN: Body of sphenoid
  • INSERTION: Upper & outer part of sclera behind the equator.
  • NERVE SUPPLY: Trochlear nerve.
  • ACTIONS: Intorsion, depression & abduction

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Inferior Rectus: This muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. In the case of oculomotor nerve palsy, the inferior rectus would be affected, leading to impaired downward movement of the eye.

 

 

Option C. Levator Palpebrae Superioris: This muscle, which elevates the upper eyelid, is also innervated by the oculomotor nerve. It would be affected in oculomotor nerve palsy, often resulting in ptosis (drooping of the eyelid).

 

Option D. Superior Rectus: Also innervated by the oculomotor nerve, the superior rectus muscle is responsible for elevating the eye. It would be impaired in oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of oculomotor nerve palsy, the superior oblique muscle, innervated by the trochlear nerve, is spared.

 

Ref: pg 359/ / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with left oculomotor nerve palsy. Which of the following movements is spared?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intorsion.

 

Option A:

 

This movement is primarily controlled by the superior oblique muscle, which is innervated by the trochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve IV), not the oculomotor nerve. Therefore, intorsion is spared in oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Explanation

 

Option B. Depression: The primary muscle for depression of the eye is the inferior rectus, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. This movement would be affected in oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Adduction: This movement is controlled by the medial rectus muscle, which is also innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Thus, adduction is impaired in oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Option D. Elevation: The superior rectus, which is responsible for elevation of the eye, is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. This movement would be compromised in oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In oculomotor nerve palsy, intorsion, controlled by the superior oblique muscle and innervated by the trochlear nerve, is the movement that is spared.

choices.text: Right Oculomotor nerve
Right Abducent nerve
Left Oculomotor Nerve
Left Abducent Nerve

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with horizontal double vision diplopia and limited abduction of the right eye, indicating the weakness of Lateral Rectus muscle of the right eye. Which cranial nerve supplies the involved muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right Abducent nerve

 

Option B:

 

The abducent nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abduction of the eye. The described symptoms – limited abduction and horizontal diplopia in right lateral gaze – are typical of a right abducent nerve palsy.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Right Oculomotor Nerve (Cranial Nerve III): This nerve innervates most of the extraocular muscles except for the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Since the lateral rectus is involved, the right oculomotor nerve is not the affected nerve in this scenario.

 

Option C. Left Oculomotor Nerve (Cranial Nerve III): This nerve controls most of the extraocular muscles of the left eye. Since the issue is with the right eye's lateral rectus muscle, this nerve is not involved in this case.

 

Option D. Left Abducent Nerve (Cranial Nerve VI):  The lateral rectus muscle of the left eye is innervated by the left abducent nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case presenting with horizontal diplopia and limited abduction of the right eye, the right abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI), which innervates the lateral rectus muscle, is implicated.

 

Ref: pg 358/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Out of all the extraocular muscles, which one is the longest?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superior oblique

 

Option B:

 

Superior oblique is the longest & thinnest of all the extraocular muscles.

 

 

  • Origin: body of sphenoid
  • Insertion: upper & outer part of sclera behind equator
  • Nerve supply: trochlear nerve
  • Actions: intorsion, depression, abduction

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Superior Rectus: This muscle originates from the common tendinous ring at the back of the orbit and inserts into the superior surface of the eyeball. It primarily causes elevation of the eye.

 

Option C. Medial Rectus: Originating from the common tendinous ring, this muscle attaches to the medial surface of the eyeball. It primarily moves the eye medially.

 

Option D. Inferior Rectus: This muscle also starts from the common tendinous ring and attaches to the inferior surface of the eyeball. Its main action is the depression of the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique is the longest extraocular muscle, primarily responsible for intorsion and depression of the eye, particularly when the eye is adducted.

 

Ref: pg 359/ / anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which extra ocular muscle is the shortest?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior oblique

 

Option C:

 

Inferior oblique is the shortest extra ocular muscle.

 

ORIGIN: orbital plate of maxilla

 

INSERTION: near insertion of lateral rectus , in front of a point corresponding to foveal region.

 

NERVE SUPPLY: oculomotor nerve

 

ACTIONS: extorsion, elevation, abduction

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Superior Rectus: This muscle, originating from the common tendinous ring, is not the shortest. It primarily elevates the eye.

 

Option B. Medial Rectus: Also arising from the common tendinous ring, this muscle is responsible for adducting the eye. It is longer compared to the inferior oblique.

 

Option D. Inferior Rectus: Originating from the common tendinous ring, this muscle primarily depresses the eye. It is not the shortest among the extraocular muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inferior oblique muscle is the shortest of the extraocular muscles, primarily responsible for extorsion, elevation, and abduction of the eye.

 

Ref: pg 360/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Superior Division of the Oculomotor Nerve
Inferior Division of Oculomotor Nerve

questions.text: Amongst the following cranial nerves, which nerve supplies the longest extraocular muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trochlear Nerve

 

Option C:

 

The Trochlear nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle, the longest extraocular muscle. The superior oblique muscle primarily causes intorsion and depression of the eye, especially when the eye is adducted.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Superior Division of the Oculomotor Nerve (Cranial Nerve III): This division supplies the superior rectus and levator palpebrae superioris muscles. The superior rectus elevates the eye, while the levator palpebrae superioris raises the upper eyelid.

 

Option B. Abducent Nerve (Cranial Nerve VI): This nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye (moves it away from the nose). It does not supply the superior oblique muscle.

 

Option D. Inferior Division of the Oculomotor Nerve (Cranial Nerve III): This division supplies the medial rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles. These muscles are involved in moving the eye medially, downwards, and in extorsion and elevation (inferior oblique), respectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve IV) supplies the superior oblique muscle, which is the longest extraocular muscle, mainly involved in intorsion and depression of the eye when adducted.

questions.text: Normal AC/A ratio is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B)  3∆-5∆

 

Option B:


The accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio is defined as the amount of convergence (in prism diopters) per unit change in accommodation (in diopters).

 

  • Normal AC/A ratio is 3∆-5∆.
  • High AC/A ratio is seen in non-refractive accommodative esotropia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 2∆-6∆: This range is slightly lower than the typical normal AC/A ratio. It would suggest less convergence per diopter of accommodation, which might be seen in cases of under-convergence.

 

Option C. 4∆-8∆: This range is on the higher side of the normal AC/A ratio. A higher ratio indicates a greater amount of convergence for each diopter of accommodation, which might be observed in cases of over-convergence.

 

Option D. 6∆-8∆: This range is usually considered higher than the normal AC/A ratio, indicating excessive convergence in response to accommodation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal AC/A ratio, indicative of the relationship between accommodative convergence and accommodation, is typically in the range of 3∆ to 5∆.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 702

questions.text: Where does the marked muscle originate from?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Annulus of Zinn

 

Option A:

 

The marked muscle is Lateral rectus, which originates from Annulus of Zinn.

 

EXTRAOCULAR MUSCLES – ORIGIN AND INSERTION

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Zygomatic bone: The zygomatic bone is a facial bone that forms the prominence of the cheek. It does not serve as an origin point for any of the extraocular muscles.

 

Option C. Body of sphenoid: None of the extraocular muscles originate from the body of sphenoid.

 

Option D. Orbital plate of maxilla: The orbital plate of the maxilla forms a large part of the floor of the orbit. However, it is not the origin point for any extraocular muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral rectus muscle originates from the Annulus of Zinn.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no 333 and KANSKI 9TH EDITION pg.no: 700

questions.text: Based on the test finding given below, what would the diagnosis be?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Esophoria

 

Option A:

 

  • The conclusion from the test is: Esophoria.
  • The given test is MADDOX ROD TEST.
  • This is done in a suspected case of heterophoria.
  • A Maddox rod consists of four or five cylinders of red glass side by side in a supporting disc and is placed in the trial frame before one eye.
  • Interpretation is as follows:

 

Esophoria:

 

  • Findings: In esophoria, the eyes tend to converge more than required when focusing on an object. When the Maddox Rod is placed in front of right eye, the patient with esophoria will see two images: a point light (seen by the uncovered eye) and a line (seen through the Maddox Rod). The line will appear to the left of the light.
  • Interpretation: The displacement of the line to the left indicates a tendency for the covered eye to turn inward, characteristic of esophoria.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Orthophoria:

 

Findings: In orthophoria, the eyes are properly aligned with each other. When using the Maddox Rod, the patient will see the point light and the line in alignment with each other.

 

Interpretation: The alignment of the line with the light indicates that there is no latent deviation of the eyes, and the ocular alignment is normal.

 

Option C. Exophoria:

 

Findings: In exophoria, the eyes tend to diverge away from each other. When the Maddox Rod is placed in front of right eye, the patient with exophoria will see the line displaced to the right of the point light

 

Interpretation: The displacement of the line to the right indicates a tendency for the covered eye to turn outward, characteristic of exophoria.

 

Option D. Hypophoria:

 

Findings: In hypophoria, there is a tendency for one eye to drift downward. When the Maddox Rod is placed horizontally in front of one eye, the patient with hypophoria will see the line displaced either above or below the light, depending on which eye is covered and the direction of the deviation.

 

Interpretation: The vertical displacement of the line indicates a tendency for the covered eye to deviate downward, characteristic of hypophoria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Maddox rod test, the point source of light is seen by the uncovered eye, while the covered eye sees the line. In esotropia, the line is displaced to left of the dot, when right eye is covered and vice-versa when left eye is covered.

 

Ref: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE PG.NO: 423

choices.text: Measurement of angle of deviation

questions.text: What is the given instrument used for?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Measurement of angle of deviation

 

Option D:

 

  • This instrument is SYNAPTOPHORE / MAJOR AMBLYOSCOPE.
  • It is used for diagnostic and therapeutic indications in orthoptics.
  • It is used for sensory function testing like
    • Estimation of grades of binocular vision
    • Detection of normal/abnormal retinal correspondence

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Determination of keratometry reading: Keratometer

 

 

Option B Field analysis: Ophthalmic Perimeter

 

Humphrey Perimeter

 

 

Option C. Measurement of axial length: Optical biometer and ultrasound biometer.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Synoptophore is used for the measurement of the angle of deviation in strabismus, as well as for the diagnosis and treatment of binocular vision anomalies.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of the eye 22nd edition – Pg 421

questions.text: When we fix our visual attention on an object of regard, the image is formed on the fovea of both our eyes separately; but we perceive a single image. Which of the following is not a component of this state of binocular single vision?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fixation

 

Option C:

 

Fixation is the ability to maintain visual gaze on a single location.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fusion:

 

Fusion is a key component of binocular single vision. It is the process by which the brain combines the two slightly different images received from each eye into a single, unified image. This is crucial for achieving binocular single vision.

 

Option B. Simultaneous Perception:

 

Simultaneous perception is also an essential component of binocular single vision. It refers to the ability of the visual system to perceive images presented to each eye simultaneously, which is a prerequisite for fusion to occur.

 

Option D. Stereopsis:

 

Stereopsis is the perception of depth that arises from the brain's processing of the slightly different images from each eye. It is a higher-level outcome of binocular single vision, but not a fundamental component of achieving binocular single vision itself. Stereopsis is dependent on the successful integration of the other components (fusion and simultaneous perception).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of binocular single vision, fixation is not a component specific to this state.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no 339

choices.text: A-i, B-iii, C-ii, D-iv
A-iv, B-ii, C-i, D-iii
A-ii, B-iii, C-iv, D-i
A-iii, B-iv, C-i, D-ii

questions.text: Match the following muscles with their primary actions:
questions.solution:
Ans. C)  A-ii, B-iii, C-iv, D-i

 

Option C:

 

  • Primary and subsidiary actions of the muscles are as follows:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superior and Inferior Rectii and Oculii have Primary and Subsidiary actions. Medial and Lateral Rectii have only primary action.

 

Ref: PARSON’S DISEASES OF THE EYE PG.NO: 405

questions.text: What is the nerve supply to the longest extraocular muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trochlear nerve

 

Option B:

 

  • Superior oblique is the longest extraocular muscle.
  • Its nerve supply is Trochlear nerve.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oculomotor Nerve (CN III): The oculomotor nerve innervates most of the extraocular muscles, including the superior, inferior, and medial recti; the inferior oblique; and the levator palpebrae superioris. However, it does not innervate the superior oblique muscle.

 

Option C. Trigeminal Nerve (CN V): The trigeminal nerve is the main sensory nerve of the face and does not innervate any of the extraocular muscles. It has three branches (ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular) that provide sensory innervation to different regions of the face.

 

Option D. Abducens Nerve (CN VI): The abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abducting the eye (moving it outward). It does not innervate the superior oblique muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nerve supply to the superior oblique muscle, the longest extraocular muscle, is the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV).

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no 333

choices.text: Contracture of direct antagonist
Overaction of contralateral antagonist
Overaction of direct antagonist

questions.text: All are true statements regarding the sequelae of extraocular muscle palsy except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Overaction of Contralateral antagonist

 

Option B:

 

Overaction of Contralateral Antagonist: This statement is not true and is the exception here. In extraocular muscle palsy, the contralateral antagonist (the muscle in the opposite eye that opposes the action of the paralyzed muscle) does not typically overact. Instead, the yoke muscle (the muscle in the opposite eye with the same action as the paralyzed muscle) may overact to compensate for the lack of movement.

 

In long-standing paralysis, secondary contractures in the antagonist muscles and soft tissues such as the conjunctiva, Tenon capsule and muscle sheaths reduce the extent of incomitance and lead to clinical features that begin to resemble comitant squint.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Contracture of Direct Antagonist: This statement is true. In cases of chronic extraocular muscle palsy, the direct antagonist can undergo contracture due to prolonged unopposed action.

 

Option C. Overaction of Direct Antagonist: This statement is true. The direct antagonist (the muscle that opposes the action of the paralyzed muscle in the same eye) overacts in response to muscle palsy because it is no longer being counteracted by the paralyzed muscle.

 

Option D. Inhibitional Palsy of Contralateral Antagonist: This statement is also true. Inhibitional palsy of the contralateral antagonist is a phenomenon observed in extraocular muscle palsy, where the antagonist of the paralyzed muscle in the opposite eye shows underaction.

 

Due to unopposed overaction of ipsilateral antagonist, there is reduced innervation of its yolk muscle, i.e. the contralateral antagonist of the paralysed muscle, following Hering’s law. This leads to a pseudoparesis of the contralateral antagonist in the early stages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incorrect statement regarding the sequelae of extraocular muscle palsy is the overaction of the contralateral antagonist. In cases of extraocular muscle palsy, common sequelae include contracture of the direct antagonist, overaction of the direct antagonist, and inhibitional palsy of the contralateral antagonist.

 

Ref: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE PG.NO 407

choices.text: A-ii, B-iii, C-iv, D-i
A-i, B-ii, C-iv, D-iii
A-iii, B-i, C-ii, D- iv
A-ii, B-i, C-iii, D-iv

questions.text: Match the following muscles with their site of insertion:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-iii, B-i, C-ii, D- iv

 

Explanation:

 

 

  • This picture shows the insertion of all four recti muscles to the sclera and their distance from the limbus.
  • The insertions are located progressively further away from the limbus in a spiral pattern.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

This The insertion of the rectii forms an imaginary line known as THE SPIRAL OF TILLAUX.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 700

choices.text: Right lateral rectus and left medial rectus
Right lateral rectus and right medial rectus
Left lateral rectus and left medial rectus
Left lateral rectus and right medial rectus

questions.text: Identify the yoke muscles in this gaze:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right lateral rectus and left medial rectus

 

Option A:

 

The movement shown in this picture is dextroversion. The muscles acting in this gaze are right LR and left MR.

 

YOKE MUSCLES – are synergists (i.e., they contract together).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Right lateral rectus and right medial rectus: These muscles work antagonistically in the same eye (right eye), so they are not yoke muscles for dextroversion.

 

Option C. Left lateral rectus and left medial rectus: These are muscles in the same eye (left eye) and work antagonistically, not as yoke muscles.

 

Option D. Left lateral rectus and right medial rectus: These muscles would be used in laevoversion (leftward gaze), not dextroversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The yoke muscles for dextroversion (rightward gaze) are the right lateral rectus and the left medial rectus. These muscles work together to move the eyes rightward.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of the eye page 407

questions.text: Identify the test:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hess chart

 

Option A:

 

  • Hess chart is used in identifying the paralyzed muscle and its sequelae.
  • The charts of both eyes are compared – smaller one (eye with paretic muscle) and larger one (eye with overacting muscle).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lees screen: A test for binocular vision anomalies, where the patient views a pattern through polarizing glasses, allowing the detection of suppression or abnormal retinal correspondence.

 

 

Option C. Lang chart: A stereo test used, often in children, to detect amblyopia and strabismus, involving a card with hidden 3D images that can only be perceived correctly with normal binocular vision.

 

 

Option D. Frisby test: A simple stereopsis test that involves viewing a series of transparent plates with embedded patterns, used to assess depth perception in patients, particularly for diagnosing amblyopia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hess chart is used in identifying the paralyzed muscle and its sequelae.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION PG.NO 353

questions.text: The inclination of lenses in each eye is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 45 º and 135 º

 

Explanation:

 

  • The test shown is Bagolini test using Bagolini striated glasses.
  • It is done for detecting Binocular single vision (BSV), Abnormal retinal correspondence (ARC) or suppression.
  •  Each lens has fine striations that convert a point source of light into a line.
  •  The two lenses are placed at 45° and 135° in front of each eye and the patient is made to fixate on a focal light source.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Bagolinni’s striated glasses the glasses are aligned as Left eye 45 º and Right Eye 135°.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PG.NO 713

questions.text: Identify the pattern of deviation:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A pattern esotropia

 

Option A:

 

  • In this picture, the amount of deviation increases in up gaze and decreases in down gaze – A pattern esotropia.

  • It is vertically incomitant horizontal strabismus.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. V pattern esotropia: A type of strabismus where the inward deviation of the eyes (esotropia) increases when looking upwards as compared to looking downwards.

 

Option C. A pattern exotropia: A form of strabismus where the outward turning of the eyes (exotropia) becomes more pronounced when the eyes are directed downwards compared to upwards.

 

Option D. V pattern exotropia: A strabismus condition characterized by an increase in the outward deviation of the eyes (exotropia) when looking upwards as compared to looking downwards.

 

Educational Objective:

 

“A” pattern esotropia is a strabismic condition where the esotropia is more pronounced when the eyes are directed downwards compared to upwards.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 355

questions.text: A patient with reading difficulty presented to ophthalmology OPD. On evaluation, the patient was found to have 6PD of esotropia with eccentric fixation. Which of the following tests would you suggest?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4PD test

 

Option A:

 

  • There is only a small angle of squint in this patient. This is known as MICROTROPIA (<10∆ squint).
  • Aka Monofixation syndrome
  • The 4-dioptre prism base-out test is useful to distinguish bifoveal fixation from foveal suppression (central suppression scotoma), which occurs during binocular viewing in patients with monofixation syndrome.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. 2PD test: Such a test is not described.

 

Option C. 6PD test: Such a test is not described.

 

Option D. 3PD test: Such a test is not described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A 4 PD test is performed on patients suspected to have small angle deviations of less than 10 prism dioptres, a microtropia, that may or may not have been observed on cover test because of subtle eye movements. The test determines whether the patient has bifoveal fixation or monofixation despite their eyes seeming straight.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PG.NO 713 & 732

questions.text: What is the given test used in assessment of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stereopsis

 

Option C:

 

  • Stereopsis refers to the perception of depth acquired through binocular vision.
  • The given test is Wirt fly test.

 

Tests for stereopsis:

 

  • Titmus test
  • TNO test
  • Frisby test
  • Lang stereotest
  • The Titmus test, which includes the Wirt fly test, is in the form of vectographs.
  • A vectograph consists of two superimposed views presented in such a way that the light entering each eye is plane polarized, the light from one view being at right angles to that from the other. The composite picture must be viewed through a polarizing visor or spectacles.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Contrast Sensitivity: This test measures the ability to discern between finer and finer increments of light versus dark (contrast), often using a chart with varying shades of gray or with spatial frequency patterns. Eg. Pelli Robson Chart.

 

 

 

Option B. Visual Acuity in Children: Various age-appropriate methods are used, such as LEA symbols, Snellen's E chart, or picture chart.

 

Option D. Malingering: Various techniques are employed, such as the fogging test or the use of duochrome test, to detect exaggeration or feigning of poor vision, often by presenting visual stimuli that are impossible to misinterpret if vision is normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Assessed using tests like the Titmus Fly test or Random Dot Stereogram, which require the patient to wear special glasses and identify 3D shapes from 2D patterns, evaluating depth perception and binocular vision.

 

Ref: Clinical optics by Elkington Page: 19
